_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP Executive Summary

1.0  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at Tampa Maid Foods.

Tampa Maid Foods prevents accidental releases through classroom and on the job training of refrigeration personnel and ongoing inspection and maintenance of the refrigeration system.  Wherever possible refrigeration system components are located in areas that are not as likely to become damaged (i.e., tanks and pipe runs are placed away and protected from forklift and truck traffic). The facility maintains an ongoing emergency response program that prepares for safe evacuation and  
timely response by trained personnel.

2.0  Tampa Maid Foods and Anhydrous Ammonia.

Tampa Maid Foods processes and freezes seafood products for global distribution. Approximately 26,843 lbs. of anhydrous ammonia is contained within the refrigeration system on site at Tampa Maid Foods. A Risk Management Plan has been developed as required and is maintained in order to reduce the possibility of an accidental release of ammonia from the system. 

3.0  Accidental Release Prevention Program and Prevention Steps.

Tampa Maid Foods complies with all rules and regulations that pertain to the safe storage and use of anhydrous ammonia. Specific regulations include: OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) rule; OSHA Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER); OSHA Hazard Communication (HAZCOM); OSHA Employee Emergency Plans and Fire Prevention Plans; EPA Risk Management Plans (RMP). 

Specific prevention steps that have been implemented to increase the safety of operation of the ammonia refrigeration system include: a 180 psi alarm was installed in the engine room to warn of high pressure conditions; a light and bell alarm was installed; the ammonia system is inspected every 2 hours, 24 hours per day; the condensers are oversized to maintain head pressure; ammonia detectors are wired to shut down refrigerant pumps and turn on ventilation fans when ammonia is detected; an e

mergency stop for the king valve is installed; an emergency stop shuts down all compressors; extensive roof top cat walks have been installed to allow safe access to all roof top piping and refrigeration equipment; all refrigeration service valves have identification tags; all refrigeration service piping is color coded; upgraded security fencing has been installed at the facility.

4.0  Five Year Accident History.

There has been one accidental release of anhydrous ammonia at Tampa Maid Foods in the last five years. On July13, 2000, a solenoid valve on the suction line serving a Gyro Freezer did not release as designed, resulting in pressure build up in the line, which caused a rupture. The sudden release of ammonia vapor traveled across the roof from the south end of the building to the northeast corner causing some employees in that area to be affected. No offsite persons were affected. Mechanical fail-safe regulators were installed on all Gyro Freezer suction lines as a back up to the solenoid valves.

5.0  Tampa Maid Foods Emergency Response Program.

Tampa Maid Foods maintains an ongoing emergency response program in order to efficiently notify and evacuate employees, notify potential critical receptors in the community and state and local emergency response agencies. The program includes initial and annual training for employees who respond to releases or potential releases. The program includes written procedures for proper first aid and emergency medical treatment to treat human exposures; procedures for using emergency response equipment and procedures to review and update the plan and ensure that employees are informed of changes. The facility emergency response plan is coordinated with the local fire department annually as required by the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act.

6.0  Planned Changes to Improve Safety at Tampa Maid Foods.

Future plans to improve anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system safety at Tampa Maid Foods include the rem

oval of six (6) air handling units in the cold room and replacing these units with four (4) penthouse units. This change will eliminate the possibility of forklift truck damage to the current units. This change is planned for October 2004. Additionally, a refrigeration system inspection and engineering audit review is completed annually by Enthalpy Exchange Consulting Engineers.
